>A URI, even an HTTP URI, that cannot be dereferenced nonetheless 
>provides a unique name for an abstract resource that can be 
>distinguished from all other names for resources.

Yes, believe me I do get that point. :)

Maybe I can re-phrase this somehow...

REST is an architectural style for referencing resources across HTTP, right?
So then, what good does "urn:i-am-foo" do me when I can't (a) GET it, (b)
POST to it, (c) PUT it, or (d) DELETE it? How do these URIs fit into the
scope of REST?

Or are we talking about two different things? I can see their use in RDF (as
mentioned in the original e-mail) as unique identifiers, but not as a
REST/HTTP resource itself.

Hmm... Maybe I'm missing something here?

Thanks,
-dave
